question: who wrote the french declaration of the rights of man and of the citizen
api_result: The French Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen, which was adopted in 1789 during the French Revolution, was primarily drafted by Marquis de Lafayette, with significant input from Thomas Jefferson, who was the American envoy to France at the time. The document was influenced by the philosophical and political ideas of the Enlightenment, such as those of Jean-Jacques Rousseau and Montesquieu. It was officially passed by the National Constituent Assembly on August 26, 1789. This declaration was a fundamental document of the French Revolution and laid out a series of individual rights and collective rights of the people. It was a key step in the development of democracy and human rights not only in France but also in other parts of the world.
